captions.text:
JAMES GRIME: OK, so today
we're going to
talk Mersenne numbers.

So we have to pick one of our
Mersenne numbers to exemplify
the category.

Now, Brady always makes me do
this, so I've decided to pick

31, because by the time
you watch this
video, I will be 31.

So it's a nice personal
number for me.

So 31 is our example of
a Mersenne prime.

So a Mersenne prime is a prime
number to begin with like 31.
31 is a prime number.

A prime number is, as you
probably know, a number that

can only be divided
by 1 and itself.

The first few prime numbers
are 2, 3, 5, 7.

31 is a prime number, but it's a
special type of prime number

because it's one less
than a power of 2.
What are the powers of 2?
Well, you've got 2.
You've got 4.

You've got 8, 16,
32, and so on.

OK, so that's just 2 times 2
times 2 times 2 times 2.
That's the sort of thing.

None of these are prime numbers,
but let's have a look
at one less.
Well, 1.

Now, if I'm honest, we
don't say 1 is prime.

There's a special
reason for that.

But let's have a look
at the others.

3 is a prime number, and it's
one less than a power of 2, so

that counts as a
Mersenne prime.

7 is a prime number, and it's
one less than a power of 2.
Fantastic.

Now that's not a prime number,
so that does not count.

And 31, there you go,
that was our example
of a Mersenne prime.

Now, there aren't many of
these Mersenne primes.

In fact, there's only
47 Mersenne primes.

Now, they start off
as 3, 7, 31.

The next one after
that is 127.

So let's have a look
at the next couple.
Powers of 2--

64, 128, and, well, this is
63, and that's not prime.
But this is 127.

That is prime, so it's one
of our Mersenne primes.

They're called Mersenne primes
because they're named after a

French mathematician called
Marin Mersenne, who was a

monk, a mathematician, and
a musician, and a fan of
alliteration.

His favorite cartoon
was Mighty Mouse.
His favorite film was Mad Max.

So he was in contact with a lot
of other mathematicians
around the world.

And he was trying to make a list
of this special type of

prime number, and that's why
they're named after him.

MALE SPEAKER: What are
they used for?

Are they used by
code breakers?

Are they used to make
better iPads?

Or are they just a game for
smart mathematicians like you?

JAMES GRIME: Well, prime numbers
are obviously very
useful to mathematicians.

They're famous, and they're
famous for a reason.

Mersenne primes are a special
types of prime number.

Something very special about
Mersenne primes, they are

related to the perfect
numbers.

We've talked about perfect
numbers before.

They were known by the
Ancient Greeks.

They were given this idea that
they were perfect, unique.

Mersenne primes and the perfect
numbers are two sides
of the same coin.
Let me show you why.

If I pick a Mersenne prime,
let's call it M
for Mersenne prime.

OK, so M is our Mersenne
prime.

Times it by M plus 1, divide by
2, and that will give you a
perfect number.
Let me show you.
3 times 4 divide by 2.
That's 12 divided by 2.
That's 6.

That was the first
perfect number.
OK, let's try the next one--
7 times 8, divide by 2.
That's 56 divide by 2.

That's the second
perfect number.
Same thing.

31 times 32, divide by 2, and
that will give you the third
perfect number--
And let's try 127.
127 times 128.
And half it, it's 8,128.
Two sides of the same coin.

Right, so you can help to find
the next Mersenne prime.

It's called The Great Internet
Mersenne Prime Search.

A great website with an
unfortunate acronym.

It's at mersenne.org, and
you can try it yourself.
Download the program.

It uses collaborative computer
power to find the next
Mersenne prime.
MALE SPEAKER: Why?
Why should I do that?
Why should anyone do that?
JAMES GRIME: For the glory.
For the glory.

Because mathematicians will
thank you for it.

Like the perfect numbers,
we don't know if there's

infinitely many perfect
numbers.

We don't know if there are
infinitely many Mersenne
primes or not.

So that's another open question,
something that

maybe, hey, you could
work out.

MALE SPEAKER: What's it going
to take to work that out?

How will that question
ever be answered?

JAMES GRIME: It's not
going to be easy.
It's not going to be obvious.

It's going to take a different
way of looking at things,

coming at it from a different
angle, something that other
people haven't tried yet.

Maybe not your usual school
math, but something else.

Whatever it is, something
we haven't tried yet.

MALE SPEAKER: The man or woman
who does that, what will it
mean for them?

If a man or a woman
comes up with that
proof, what will happen?

JAMES GRIME: If you do you come
up with that proof, you

will have glory thrust
upon you.

You will be famous for coming
up with such a proof,

something that has eluded
mathematicians
for hundreds of years.

MALE SPEAKER: Is it something
you can have a hunch about?

JAMES GRIME: Yeah, I think
technically we would have to

be Mersenne prime agnostic, but
it's definitely something
you have a hunch for.
Mathematics is done that way.

People think mathematics is a
dry subject, that is logical.
But people have intuition.

They have to pursue
their intuition.

So if you ask me, I would say
yeah, infinite number of
Mersenne primes?
Yeah, I would think so.
I might be wrong.

"A fan of alliteration" 
As you probably already know: Rhyme, is when the *end* of consecutive words 
sound the same. 
Alliteration is when the *start* of consecutive words in a sentence sound 
the same...

comments.author: Martha E

comments.text:
Mersenne numbers also happen to tell you how many moves are in the optimal 
solution for the old 'towers of Hanoi' or 'tower of London' puzzles. For 
example, when you have 6 disks, the optimal solution takes 63 moves. 
(2^6=64, 64-1=63)﻿

comments.author: James Ede

comments.text:
It seems like your English comprehension needs some work. I know my above 
example is false, that's the point. I used the example to show you why your 
reasoning was invalid. It's called a counterexample.

The bottom line is that you argued that if a set A is a subset of an 
infinite set B, then A must be infinite. And as I showed above, that is not 
true.
comments.author: tj12711

comments.text:
+Alejandro Magno Mantilla Castellanos
"MP € set[p]
set[p] is infinite
Every MP is a p
Therefore set[MP] is infinite"

Again, this does not logically follow. Assume that:

A is a set (which we do not know if it is infinite or finite)
B is an infinite set.

If B € A, then A is infinite
However, if A € B, we do not have enough information to determine if A is 
finite or infinite.

Allow me to use a counterexample to show the fault in your reasoning.

A = {2, 5, 13}
P = The set of all primes {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, ...}
A € P
P is infinite
Every element of A is also an element of P
Therefore, A is infinite.

This is clearly false because A has only 3 terms. In set theory, a set is 
infinite if and only if for every natural number the set has a subset whose 
cardinality is that natural number.

Until you show that for every natural number, the mersenne primes has a 
subset whose cardinality is that natural number, you have not shown that it 
is infinite.
comments.author: tj12711

comments.text:
+Alejandro Magno Mantilla Castellanos
well set{2,3} € set[p] but set{2,3} is not infinite.
Also:
set[MP] € set[p] but set[MP] does not have to be infinite.
comments.author: TheKilogram1000

comments.text:

conjectures before proofs, and the conjectures tend to make it easier to

comments.author: TheKilogram1000

comments.text:
+Alejandro Magno Mantilla Castellanos
Let me try to explain to you the flaw in your reasoning using logical 
arguments. Essentially, your argument can be phrased as:

All A (Mersenne Primes) are B (Prime)
All C (Full lists of infinite sequences) contain B (Primes)
Therefore, all C (Full lists of infinite sequences) contain A (Mersenne 
Primes)

Looking at the above example, the premises are both true, but the 
conclusion does not follow. If all A are B, and all B are C, then all A are 
C. HOWEVER, just because all A are B, and all C are B, does not mean all A 
are C.

For instance, observe the following argument:

All dogs are mammals
All humans are mammals
Therefore, all humans are dogs

is obviously not true. This is one of the most common misuses of logic, as 
it can sometimes be used to make arguments that sound legit but are in fact 
false.
comments.author: tj12711

comments.text:

need to. It's really hard to find proofs.

comments.text:
+Alejandro Magno Mantilla Castellanos

How about this
M_p = (2^p) - 1 where p is a prime number.
This only works sometimes.
Ex:
2^(3) - 1 =M_p = 7.
This works
Counter example (contraejemplo):
2^(11) - 1 = M_p = 2047.
This does not work this is divisible by 23. (Es divisible por 23)
Therefore
2^(p) - 1 = M_p sometimes (a veces). We don't know if there are infinite 
primes that make this work or if there is a finite amount of primes that 
make this work.
comments.author: TheKilogram1000

comments.text:
+PokemonTom09 Since when did we not know that primes were infinite? The 
proof is easy for that one. 

Assume primes are finite. This means that you can make a list of every 
prime number. Multiply all of those numbers together. Add 1. This new 
number is not divisible by any of the other prime numbers. This number as 
such must be prime. However, since primes were assumed to be finite, this 
is a contradiction. Therefore, primes must be infinite. 

This sort of proof is quite handy in mathematics, and is called proof by 
contradiction. Basically, it is proving sometimes by showing that there is 
a contradiction if it is not true.
comments.author: NowhereManForever

comments.text:
+TheKilogram1000 "Infinite integers = infinite Mersenne Primes"
That's like saying that because there are an infinate amount of integers 
there are an infinate amout of whole numbers between 0 and 10. Not even 
close to a solid connection.

Also, this entire thread has been running off the assumption that there are 
an infite number of prime numbers, but even that hasn't been proven yet.
Mathmaticians are pretty sure there are an infinate amount, but that is in 
no way conclusive. So basically, your argument that "Infinate primes means 
infite Mersenne primes," -- which is already a pretty big assumption -- is 
fundimentally based on another assumption.

Another thing that you assumed is that it has been proven that there are an 
infinate amount of perfect numbers, despite the fact that James *literally 
explained in this video* that it is still unknown if there are an infinate 
amount of perfect numbers
comments.author: PokemonTom09

comments.text:
This is not always true even though there are an infinite number of 
integers. For example, Fermat conjectured that all numbers of the form 
2^(2^m) + 1 were prime. Not only is this not true, but there are only five 
numbers for which this is true. This conjecture was disproven by Euler for 
your information. I would suggest a book called "Journey Through Genius: 
The Great Theorems of Mathematics". If I remember right, this book mentions 
this proof.

Anyway, no it is not guaranteed that there are an infinite number of 
Mersenne primes.

comments.text:
again, you are wrong- there are plenty of examples of sequences that end, 
sequences for which there are a finite set. I gave you some in my last 
comment. Platonic solids are another- infinity is a complex idea for which 
there are not easy rules like "if there's one prime there's infinite 
primes". It is in fact proved that there are infinitely many prime numbers, 
but it is not proved that there infinitely many mersenne primes. Your 
reasoning, if sound, should work for any given number, it doesn't
comments.author: Samuel Marks

comments.text:
I didn't mean "1". I meant if there's one prime there's infinite primes. I 
think you don't realize what infinity really means. Truly, if there's one 
of something, then there's infinite. Over and over and over and over. Many 
worlds, parallel, however you look at it. Time itself is never going to 
stop. It will continue towards infinity even if there are no observers. 
There are different infinities as well, but I'm talking linear. Not 
imaginary, like 2.549836354589299437499209298-------- and so on.
comments.author: immasmashyourface

comments.text:
this is false, for example- there is a "1" in the number line, but there is 
only one "1" any other number may contain "1" but it is not , in fact "1". 
there are more examples; munschausen numbers being just one. infinity does 
not mean what you think it means
comments.author: Samuel Marks

comments.text:
no, because the ned result is found BY dividing by two, so just as (for 
example) 6 divided by 2 is 3 (not an even number), an equation ending in a 
/2 does not necessarily produce an even result. so this equation producing 
mersene primes will not always produce odd numbers

Absolutely right. 1, 3, 7, 15, 31, 63, 127, 255, . Each one plus 1 is 2 
times the previous number. If you know that powers of 2 in binary always 
need a an added digit(case 255 i.e. 11111111 and Pacman)so the previous one 
will always be only 1s. 2 to the power x - 1 in decimal is equal to x 
number of 1s in binary.

comments.text:
No... what you have proven there is that there are infinite numbers. Not 
that there are infinite Mersenne primes. I could wrongly use this to claim 
"there are infinitely many even primes". This is obviously incorrect, but 
hey, there are infinite numbers, so it must be true, right? Or, if you 
don't like that, how about infinitely many Munchausen numbers? Again, there 
are infinitely many numbers. But, as it turns out, there's just one 
Munchausen number.
